qas.question: What specifically dates back with Confucius in the 6th century BC?
Chinese political philosophy dates back to what century?
Chinese political philosophy was developed as a response to what?

answers.text: the social and political breakdown of the country

qas.question: What advocated a communal, decentralized government centered on frugality and ascetism?
What dates back to the 6th century AD?
What was a response to increased social and political awareness in China?
What advocated a communal, centralized government centered on frugality and accetism?
Who advocated a government based on empathy, loyalty and personal relationships?
Who advocated a peasant uprising and egalitarianism?
What is attributed to Mencius in the 6th Century BC?
What attribute did all of the philosophies share?
In what Spring and Autumn period was Legalism dominant?
In the Qin Dynasty, what replaced Legalism?

context: <a0_0><b4_0><b10_0>Chinese political philosophy<b10_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> dates back to <b9_0>the Spring and Autumn Period<b9_0/>, specifically with Confucius in the <a1_0>6th century BC<a1_0/>. <b5_0>Chinese political philosophy<b5_0/> was developed as a response to <a2_0>the social and political breakdown of the country<a2_0/> characteristic of the Spring and Autumn Period and the Warring States period. The major philosophies during the period, Confucianism, Legalism, <b6_0>Mohism<b6_0/>, Agrarianism and Taoism, each had <b11_0>a political aspect<b11_0/> to their philosophical schools. Philosophers such as <b7_0>Confucius<b7_0/>, Mencius, and Mozi, focused on political unity and political stability as the basis of their political philosophies. Confucianism advocated a hierarchical, meritocratic government based on empathy, loyalty, and interpersonal relationships. Legalism advocated a highly authoritarian government based on draconian punishments and laws. <a3_0>Mohism<a3_0/> advocated a communal, decentralized government centered on frugality and ascetism. The <b8_0>Agrarians<b8_0/> advocated a peasant utopian communalism and egalitarianism. Taoism advocated a proto-anarchism. Legalism was the dominant political philosophy of the <b12_0>Qin Dynasty<b12_0/>, but was replaced by <b13_0>State Confucianism<b13_0/> in the Han Dynasty. Prior to China's adoption of communism, State Confucianism remained the dominant political philosophy of China up to the 20th century.
